In this application exercise, we will use bootstrapping to construct confidence intervals.

## Packages

We will use **tidyverse** and **tidymodels** for data exploration and modeling, respectively, and the **openintro** package for the data, and the **knitr** package for formatting tables.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)
library(tidymodels)
library(openintro)
library(knitr)
```
:::


## Data

The data are on houses that were sold in the Duke Forest neighborhood of Durham, NC around November 2020.
It was originally scraped from Zillow, and can be found in the `duke_forest` data set in the **openintro** R package.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
glimpse(duke_forest)
```

## Model


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
df_fit <- linear_reg() |>
  set_engine("lm") |>
  fit(price ~ area, data = duke_forest)

tidy(df_fit) |>
  kable(digits = 2)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}


|term        |  estimate| std.error| statistic| p.value|
|:-----------|---------:|---------:|---------:|-------:|
|(Intercept) | 116652.33|  53302.46|      2.19|    0.03|
|area        |    159.48|     18.17|      8.78|    0.00|


:::
:::


## Bootstrap confidence interval

### 1. Calculate the observed fit (slope)


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
observed_fit <- duke_forest |>
  specify(price ~ area) |>
  fit()

observed_fit
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 2 × 2
  term      estimate
  <chr>        <dbl>
1 intercept  116652.
2 area          159.
```


:::
:::


### 2. Take *n* bootstrap samples and fit models to each one.

Fill in the code, then set `eval: true` .


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
n = 100
set.seed(20251125)

boot_fits <- duke_forest |>
  specify(price ~ area) |>
  generate(reps = n, type = "bootstrap") |>
  fit()

boot_fits
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 200 × 3
# Groups:   replicate [100]
   replicate term      estimate
       <int> <chr>        <dbl>
 1         1 intercept 340808. 
 2         1 area          73.4
 3         2 intercept  79713. 
 4         2 area         175. 
 5         3 intercept  85114. 
 6         3 area         183. 
 7         4 intercept 144051. 
 8         4 area         142. 
 9         5 intercept -55286. 
10         5 area         227. 
# ℹ 190 more rows
```


:::
:::


-   Why do we set a seed before taking the bootstrap samples?

-   Make a histogram of the bootstrap samples to visualize the bootstrap distribution.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
boot_fits |>
  filter(term == "area") |>
  ggplot(aes(x = estimate)) +
  geom_histogram()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value `binwidth`.
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](ae-15-duke-forest-bootstrap-A_files/figure-html/boot-hist-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


### 3. Compute the 95% confidence interval as the middle 95% of the bootstrap distribution

Fill in the code, then set `eval: true` .


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
get_confidence_interval(
  boot_fits,
  point_estimate = observed_fit,
  level = 0.95,
  type = "percentile"
)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 2 × 3
  term      lower_ci upper_ci
  <chr>        <dbl>    <dbl>
1 area          78.3     212.
2 intercept -18861.   297587.
```


:::
:::


## Changing confidence level

### Modify the code from Step 3 to create a 90% confidence interval.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
get_confidence_interval(
  boot_fits,
  point_estimate = observed_fit,
  level = 0.90,
  type = "percentile"
)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 2 × 3
  term      lower_ci upper_ci
  <chr>        <dbl>    <dbl>
1 area          94.9     198.
2 intercept  21288.   289304.
```


:::
:::


### Modify the code from Step 3 to create a 99% confidence interval.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
get_confidence_interval(
  boot_fits,
  point_estimate = observed_fit,
  level = 0.99,
  type = "percentile"
)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 2 × 3
  term      lower_ci upper_ci
  <chr>        <dbl>    <dbl>
1 area          73.9     227.
2 intercept -59585.   330014.
```


:::
